summary: This document contains notes from a September 29, 2021 interview regarding the Metropolitan Correctional Center's camera system failures around the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death. The interviewee, a technical staff member, discusses system malfunctions, repair attempts, and access issues, revealing that half the cameras were not recording in early August 2019. This document appears to be a detailed interview or testimony from a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) employee, likely a computer technician or facilities staff member, regarding the failure and repair of video surveillance systems at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) around the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death. The interviewee discusses technical issues, access problems, and institutional priorities, suggesting systemic neglect of the camera system prior to the incident.

events.title: Camera Recorders Stop Working / Motherboard Replaced
events.description: The interviewee first hears that the camera recorders stopped working on this date. He also states he replaced the motherboard on DVR 2 on this date and believed it started working.

events.title: Camera System Check and Repair Attempt
events.description: The interviewee was with a BOP electrician working on a new camera system rack. He also later states he may have replaced the motherboard on this date, causing confusion.

events.title: Discovery of Widespread Camera Failure
events.description: The interviewee first found out half the camera recorders were not working. One half was on DVR 1 and the other on DVR 2.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died in his cell. The document references system failures leading up to this date and notes SigNet installed new recorders the day after.

events.title: FBI Interview
events.description: The interviewee confirms he was interviewed by the FBI on this date and was read the report.

events.title: Documented Interview
events.description: The date of the interview from which these notes were taken, reviewing the 2019 camera system failures.

events.title: Camera System Failure Identified
events.description: The interviewee is notified of a problem with the surveillance cameras (DVR-2). He calls SigNet for support and begins seeking replacement parts but cannot access the SIS room to make repairs.

events.title: Access Denied for Repairs
events.description: The interviewee obtains replacement drives but is denied access to the SIS evidence room by SIS Teech, who is leaving for the day. Repairs are postponed.

events.title: Drive Replacement and FBI Intervention
events.description: The interviewee gains access to the SIS room, removes two bad drives from DVR-2, and begins rebuilding the system. The FBI arrives, stops the work, and seizes all drives from DVR-2.

events.title: FBI Seizure of Remaining Drives
events.description: The FBI returns and seizes all drives from the second DVR unit (DVR-1). A new camera system is installed at the MCC.

events.title: Prior System Failure
events.description: A system failure of DVR-2 occurred, possibly involving a motherboard issue. This date is noted in the SigNet report and FBI 302 as when recording may have stopped.

locations: Computer server room (first floor of MCC)
keyFacts: Half of the camera recorders at the MCC were not working on August 9, 2019, just before Jeffrey Epstein's death.
The interviewee, the only person with access to the 'Supervision' camera monitoring application, had no training on it and did not use it to check system status.
The camera system was 15 years old, running 24/7, and prone to hard drive failures; a failure of two drives in one DVR would cause all cameras on that DVR to stop recording.
The interviewee gave conflicting statements about whether he repaired the system on July 29 or August 8, 2019.
SigNet, the vendor, installed new camera recorders the day after Epstein's death, when the MCC became a 'priority.'
The interviewee states that surveillance camera failures were a recurring, known problem at the MCC for months or years, treated as a low priority until after Jeffrey Epstein's death.
Replacing the two bad hard drives on August 10, 2019, would have wiped all prior video data from DVR-2, making recovery impossible.
The FBI intervened on August 10-11, 2019, seizing all DVR drives, which halted the repair process and preserved the drives as evidence.
The interviewee felt made a "fall guy," arguing that management ignored his prior warnings about the failing camera system and only treated it as urgent after the high-profile incident.
Access to the SIS evidence room, which housed the DVR equipment, was controlled by SIS staff, creating delays in repairs on August 8 and 9.
